 Foreword The explosion of international migration in the Middle East and North Africa. Region in the 1970s was a major development on the international economic scene with profound implications for both the labor-importing and the labor-exporting countries. The World Bank undertook a research study on the subject in 1978 under the leadership of Ismail Serageldin and his group of committed colleagues in the Technical Assistance and Special Studies Division of the EMENA Projects Department. The study was completed in 1981 and the Report has been widely disseminated. It has been published in book form this year. 1/ The set of simulation models developed by the Technical Assistance and Special Studies Division and elaborated during the research project has been applied to study manpower problems and planning issues in several countries and proven to be a useful tool for manpower planning. The wide availability and a full description of these models is important and to be welcomed. Vinod Dubey Chief Economist Europe, Middle East and North Africa Region May 1983 1/ Ismail Serageldin, James A. Socknat, Stace Birks, Bob Li, and Clive Sinclair, Manpower and International Labor Migration in the Middle East and North Africa (Oxford University Press for the World Bank, 1983). v

 Preface This document, published in four volumes as part of the World Bank's staff working papers, is intended to set forth the mathematical formulation of the Bank's various Manpower Planning Models, most of which have now been used in a number of countries and studies, but whose technical documentation was not hitherto available to the public. Applied Models are living entities, constantly changing and (we hope) improving to meet the new requirements introduced by their users. The present publication must therefore be seen as a snapshot in time, but one which presents the interested user with the opportunity of reviewing the technical documentation as well as the user's guides as they stand at the beginning of 1983. They are not likely to change significantly until a new round of intensive applications produces a new generation. The technical presentation provides, for completeness, a detailed discussion (pp. 98-132) of a simultaneous procedure method for the migration model. This has not been implemented to date, partly because time and resources constraints prevented its complete development and elaboration, but it nevertheless sketches out the likely direction of our next round of research and development efforts, planned for 1983/84. It is important to emphasize, however, that while we were the main protagonists in the development of these models, the work would not have been possible without the support, guidance and incisive comments of many colleagues in and outside the Bank. To all of them we owe a great debt of intellectual and moral gratitude. We emphasize, however,-that any errors or shortcomings in the present manuscript are purely our own.

 Note The purpose of this User's Guide for the Regional (Expanded) Model is to describe the input, output, use, and operation of the Regional (Expanded) Model, a manpower forecasting model, implemented for IBM 370 systems. Staff of the Technical Assistance and Special Studies (TASS) Division of the World Bank are available, under appropriate arrangements, to discuss with potential users the collection and preparation of required input data for running the Model. In some cases, the TASS Division can also conduct short orientation and training sessions on the capabilities and operation of the Model.
 Table of Contents Section 1.0 Introduction ............... 1 Section 2.0 Overview .................. 4 Section 3.0 System Outputs ............ 10 Section 4.0 System Inputs ............. 20 Appendix A Card Formats .............. 44 Appendix B Diagnostic Outputs ........ 101 xi

 Section 1.0 Introduction The purpose of this interim User's Guide is to provide information to users of the Regional Manpower Planning Model (The Expanded Model) on the features and design of the Expanded Model, on what reports/outputs are avail- able and on how to prepare input data, when available, for regional manpower forecasting and analysis. The detailed discussions of the Expanded Model are given in the Discussion Paper # 1, An Expanded Manpower Planning Model for Regional Manpower Analyses Internal Specifications, Dated January 16, 1978. In the original Compound Model, a country is treated as a single unit, in which estimated manpower stocks, requirements and supplies, though disaggregated by sector/occupation matrices and by nationality, do not have any breakdown by geographic regions. The emphasis of the original Compound Model is on stock analysis. But the Expanded Model will include both regional and national manpower analyses including but not limited to inter-regional labor force migration, and the associated movement of non-labor force due to labor force migration. The Expanded Model emphasizes both stock analyses and flow analyses at both national and subnationl (regional) levels. The reports and outputs to be produced by the Expanded Model are discussed in detail in Section 3.0 System Outputs. The users of the Expanded Model have options to select one or more or all of the reports at the selected years of projections. It is not intended to have all the available reports analyzed by one individual. On the contrary, it is recommended that a team of specialists be assembled, and each of them analyzes reports produced in their field of expertise. Tnrough this team effort, various sensitivity analyses should then be conducted and analyzed.
 Among the reports described in Section 3.0, the following Ymeports are of particular interest for flow analyses at both the national and the subnational levels: (1) National Labor Force Stock by Sector and Occupation (Report ID LOI), by Occupation and by Year (Report ID L02) and by Sector and by Year (Report ID L03), which give ana- lyses, inter alia, on the leakage of nationals during a given year and labor force movements through the gain from, or the loss due to, reallocation of leaked national labor force; (2) Population ReDorts (Report ID S05 and Report ID S06), which summarize the population by locality, age group, sex, nationality as well as estimated flows on move- ins, move-outs, death and birth; (3) Available Manpower Pool Analyses (Report ID P08), and Regional Manpower Leakage Analyses (Report ID P09), which provide information, inter alia, on labor force waiting in transient state, the number of total leakers avail- able for reallocation as well as the number of leakers distributed to each region in the country. (4) Highlight Reports including Labor Force Highlight Report (Report ID H01), Manpower Surplus/Shortage Report (Report ID H02), and Additional Achievable Outputs Due to Labor Force in Transient State (Report ID H03), which provide information on surplus/deficit manpower, and additional
 achieveable outputs that are obtainable if those labor force in transient state are allocated for productive uses. Past experience in the uses of the Compound Model indicate that the initial data preparation is the most time consuming part of the exercise. This could also be true for the uses of the Expanded Model. Many different types of expertise are required to analyze what data are available, how to classify sector/occupation categories, how to construct the'education training system, and how to prepare various input parameters that are required for the uses of the Compound Model or the Expanded Model. But this is not the unique problem to the Compound Model or the Expanded Model only; it is a common symptom for the uses of all models, regardless of the scale of the models. However, once the base case data are collected, and analyzed, sensitivity analysis can be easily done by changing only the data that are affected. It is through sensitivity analyses that the users of the Expanded Model should try to derive their policy recommendations and the potential consequences of the recommended policy choices. This interim User's Guide is prepared primarily for the users of the Expanded Model to start collecting data and when available, put in key punch forms as described in Appendix A Card Formats. A finalized version of User's Guide is being prepared to replace this interim User's Guide. Any question regarding data preparation for the Expanded Model should be addressed to: Technical Assistance and Special Studies Division The World Bank 1818 H Street N.W. Washington D.C. 20433, U.S.A.
 -4- Section 2.0 Overview 2.1 General Description of the Model Designs The system is divided into 3 modules, according to their function, as shown in Figure 2.1. The first module is the edit module which checks all of the data for errors and generates an optional listing for the user of the input deck. The input cards are described in general in Section 4.0 and in detail in Appendix A. The second module is the simulation module where the input data is actually used to calculate manpower projections. The model contains several submodels. These submodels are: (i) Labor Force Model; (ii) Manpower Requirement Model; (iii) Educational Simulation Model (ESM); and (iv) Manpower Policy Model. The Labor Force Model maintains the national and expatriate labor force for each locality on an annual basis. Starting from base year informa- tion, the model applies an annual attrition rate to expatriates and attrition as well as leakage rates to nationals. The ltaked national labor force is then re-allocated among localities within the country. The Labor Force Model also accounts for the move-ins, move-outs and supplies from available labor force. The Manpower Requirements Model calculates the total manpower requirements by sector/occupational categories to achieve the desired tar- get outputs. It also calculates the net manpower requirements by sector/ occupational categories after comparing the total manpower and the available
 -5- vta Master Input Data Start ~~~FiLe Diagnostics 7 $ $ SV < | ~~~~~~OptionaL| nput ecEdit Data Formtte I m~~~~Et l Simulation _ ~~~~Run SimuLation ba~~ Diagnostics . ILModuLeI te,- l H~~~~~~~e l Rept Reports_ I ModuLe I . [~~~~~~~Selected| L 2.1 _ pdt o Overvie Figure 2.1 Expanded M,odel Overview
 - 6 - manpower stock. There is a capability to directly input manpower requirements for sectors which have readily available data. Also, teacher requirements may be summed directly from the Educational Simulation Model (ESM). The Education/Training Simulation Model (ESM) is based upon a sim- plified version of a model developed by UN'ESCO. It has specific new capabili- ties to meet the need of the Expanded Model's objectives, including the abilities to: (i) Forecast school leavers by age and by educational level; (ii) Forecast number of school leavers who will participate in the labor force; and (iii) Maintain pools of those who are below the legal minimum age to participate in the labor force. The Manpower Policy Model (MPM) compares the net manpower require- ments against manpower supplies from the educational systems, and attempts to allocate them in accordance with a priority matrix, in which the priority and proportion of nationalization in each sector/occupation are specified by policy makers. In addition, MPM also estimates global achievable output, labor force in transient state, net requirements for expatriates and surplus/ deficient national manpower in each locality. The final module is the reports module. It takes the outputs of the various submodels of the simulation module and generates the reports described in Section 3.0. Consolidation reports for the country as a whole are also generated by the report module.
 -7- Together, these four submode.ls perform simulation runs for the fol- lowing functions: 1. Estimate labor force inventories and leakages; 2. Estimate labor force requirements; 3. Estimate manpower supplies from education/training systems; 4. Perform labor force supply poolings; 5. Perform manpower allocation of current year school leavers according to poolings; 6. Re-allocate labor force leakages to localities with time lags taken into account; 7. Estimate non-labor force movements due to labor force movements with time lags taken into account; 8. Calculate local net manpower requirements; 9. Calculate local achievable outputs; 10. Calculate national net manpower requirements; 11. Calculate national achievable outputs; 12. Estimate net importation/exportation of expatriates at both the local and the national levels. 2.2 Input Capability Improvements over the Original Compound Model In addition to the major capabilities of the Expanded Model for stock and flow analyses on labor force and non-labor force movements as des- cribed above, there are several improvements in input capabilities relative to those of the original Compound Model. These improvements are described in the remainder of this section:
 - 8 - (1) In the original Education/Training Submodel a limitation of not more than 12 follow-on courses was imposed. This limitation has now been removed. In the Expanded Model, there is no limitations on the number of follow-on courses. (2) The D cards have been substantially revised. The streaming cards can now be used jointly to specify interpolation points and a number of interpolation intervals rather than a single one (i.e. only the first year and the last year of simulation run). In addition, growth rates can also be applied after the interpola- tion intervals rather than for the entire range of years. Thus, a combination of direct entry, interpolation, and growth rates can be used for a single sector. (3) New options have been made available on E06 Card (PRDD and Repetition/Dropout Data Card). These options are: (i) If 0 or blank, then both Repetition/Dropout rates and PRDD's are present; (ii) If 1, then only the Repetition/Dropout rates are present; (iii) If 2, then only PRDD's are present; and (iv) If 3, then the Repetition/Dropout and PRDD values are to be added to last year's values to obtain new Repetition/Dropout rates and PRDD's. (4) Labor pools are now identified by a 3-character alpha-numeric code rather than a number. This provides greater flexibility and allows the use of the "ALL" option on some cards to specify all labor pools.
 (5) An option to allow users of the Expanded Model to group certain sectors together for the highlights reports has been introduced using GIO card. In the original Compound Model, this sector grouping for the highlights reports could not be defined by users. (6) To make the Expanded Model as general purpose a model as pos- sible, the users of the Expanded Model can now specify in the COI card the ID of the nationals so the users have complete flexibility in assigning IDs to the nationalities on the G04 cards. (7) Several options have been introduced into the Expanded Model to provide the users increased flexibility in specifying the method whereby expatriates are assigned to unfilled positions. These include (i) current proportions of expatriates are continued in each sector/occupation, (ii) user-supplied new proportions are to be maintained after importation or exportation of required expatriates to fill in shortages, and (iii) user-supplied propor- tions are to be applied to unfilled expatriate positions. The technique employed can vary between sector/occupation combina- tions and simulation years. (8) The Edit Module for the Expanded Model has been improved to pro- vide more complete checking of input data than was done for the original Compound Model. Error messages are more specific and fields in error are underlined. A listing of error diagnostics can be found in Appendix C.
 - 10 - Section 3.0 System Outputs The model will generate four major outputs which are briefly de- scribed in this section. The outputs are: (1) Reports; (2) Master File (output from Edit step); (3) Expanded Model Output File; and (4) Diagnostic Output. The contents of reports generated by the Expanded Model are described in the remainder of this section. The master file generated by the Edit Module and the Expanded Model output file generated by the Edit Module and the Simulation Module are described in the manual Programming Documentation, to be issued separately. The diagnostic outputs which describe errors committed in input preparations are in Appendix C.
 3.1 Reports This secti.,n describes each of the reports in the Expanded Model system. Sample reports can be found in Appendix B. It is recommended that Users of the Expanded Model refer to those sample reports while studying this section. The reports are labeled with a 3-letter code (e.g., MOI, M02, etc.) beginning with a letter which identifies the type of report. The years to be included in the reports as well as the report ID's can be separately selected for each locality and for the global output. The reports are selected using the G05 card, with the years being specified on the C03 card. The reports can be divided into five major categories: (i) Labor Force Status Reports; (ii) Manpower Requirements Reports; (iii) Education/Training and Manpower Supply Reports; (iv) Manpower Policy Implications Reports; and (v) Highlights Reports. The first four major categories correspond to the four major submodels of the Compound Model. Labor Force Status Reports include: (LOI) National Labor Force Stock by Sector and by Occupation (Report ID L01) For each selected year, this report gives an overall view of the national labor force stock by sector and by occupation. It contains the following items: A. The existing national labor force at the beginning of a year; B. The attrition during the year;
 - 12 - C. The leakage of nationals during the year; D. The available labor force after attrition and leakage; E. Current year allocation of school leavers; F. Labor gained from reallocation of leakage; and G. Total labor available at the end of the year. (L02) National Labor Force Stock by Occupation and by Year (Report ID L02) This report gives the same information as Report LOI except that the information is summed across sectors. All selected report years are combined into a single table. (L03) National Labor Force Stock by Sector and by Year (Report ID L03) This report gives the same information as Report LOI except that the information is summed across occupations. All selected report years are combined into a single table. (NOl) Ex-patriate Labor Force Analvses by lUationalitv. bv Sector, by OccuDation (Report ID NOl) For each selected year this report gives expatriate labor force stock by sector and by occupation, for each expatr:i .: nationality. It has the following contents: A. The existing expatriates at the beginning of a year; B. The attrition during the year; C. The number available after attrition; D. The expatriate labor force required to fill the manpower shortage (these data are obtained from the solution in the Manpower Policy Submodel); and E. The net importation/exportation of expatriates.
 - 13 - (N02) Expatriate Labor Force Analyses by Sector and by Occupation (Report ID N02) This report gives the same information as Report NOI except that the information is summed across nationalities. (N03) Expatriate Labor Force Analyses by Occupation and by Year (Report ID N03) This report gives the same information as Report NOI except that the information is summed across nationalities and sectors. All selected report years are combined into a single table. (N04) Expatriate Labor Force Analyses by Sector and by Year (Report ID N04) This report gives the same information as Report N01 except that the information is summed across nationalities and occupations. All selected report years are combined into a single table. (N05) Expatriate Labor Force Analyses by Nationality and by Year (Report ID N05) This report gives the same information as Report N01 except that the information is summed across sectors and occupations. All selected report years are combined into a single table. (N06) Expatriate Labor Force Analysis by Nationality. Locality and Year (Report ID N06) This report is available only for the global analyses. It provides a listing of the existing expatriate labor force in the country by nationality and locality. All selected report years are combined into a single table.
 - 14 - Manpower Requirements Reports include: (Mol) Target Sectoral Products and Expected Manpower Requirements by Sector and by Occupation (Report ID M0o) For each selected year, this report provides information about the target and achievable sectoral production as well as the required and available sectoral manpower. The manpower figures are further broken down by occupational categories. Available manpower figures are broken down into national and expatriate figures. Totals across sectors are given for all figures. (M02) Target Sectoral Products and Expected Manpower Requirements by Sector and by Year (Report ID M02) This report combines the sectoral information from the yearly M01 reports into a single presentation, giving information for all selected report years together. The manpower breakdown by occupation in the M01 report is not presented in this smmary report. ESM Educational System Reports include: (Sol) Education/Training System Description by Course (Report ID S01) For each selected year this report lists the enrollments, graduation and dropout rates and follow-on course numbers on a course by course basis. (S04) Education/Training System Enrollment by Teacher Group (Report ID S04) For each selected year this report lists the enrollment within each teacher group, the change in that enrollment since the previous year, the desired student teacher ratio, and the resulting net number of teachers required.
 - 15 -- (S05) Population of a Locality by Nationality, Sex, and Age Group (Report ID S05) For each selected year this report summarizes the population of the locality by age group and sex, for each nationality. It includes a summary of those who, during the year, moved in or moved out or died as well as those who were born. (S06) Total Population of a Locality by Sex and Age Group (Report ID S06) This report contains the same information as report S05, summed across nationalities. Manpower Policy Implication Reports include: (P01) Pooling Report of Manpower Supplies from the Educational/ Training System (Report ID P01) For each selected year this report gives a detailed account of how graduates/dropouts from the educational/training system are pooled. It contains: A. the course number; B. the pool number; C. the number of graduates/dropouts; D. those filtered; E. those totalled by pools; and F. those leaked to the same or other regions totalled by pools. (P02) Allocation of Pooled School Leavers by Sector and by Occupation (Report ID P02) For each selected year this report gives a detailed analysis of the allocations of pooled school leavers in accordance with a national priority matrix of various sectors/occupations.
 - 16 - (P03) Nationalization Programs Analyses by Sector and by Occupation (Report ID P03) For each selected year this report gives a detailed comparison of sectoral/occupational manpower requirements for the expected sectoral products and the existing available national labor force. It contains: A. the sectoral/occupational manpower requirements; B. the existing national labor force; C. the fraction of nationalization expressed in percent; D., the number of nationals needed by the nationalization; E. the difference between the existing national labor force and the number of nationals needee for nationalization; F. the current year manpower supplies from the educational/ training system for the given sector/occupation; G. the current year manpower supplies from reallocation of leakage; and E. the net additional nationals needed to satisfy the nationalization program for the given sector/occupation. (P04) Nationality Analyses of Labor Force by Sector and bv Occupation (Report ID P04) For each selected year this report gives a detailed account of total labor force by nationality for each sector/occupation expressed as percent within the sector/occupational matrix.
 - 17 - (P05) Nationalitv Analvses of Labor Force by Sector and bv Year (Report ID P05) This report gives a detailed account of the labor force by nationality, expressed as percent, within a given sector for the selectea report years. (P06) Nationality Analvses of Labor Force by Occupation and bv Year (Report ID P06) This report gives a detailed account of the labor force by nationality, expressed as percent, within a given occupation for the selected report years. (P07) Comparative Analvses of Target Outputs and Achievable Outputs by Sector (Renort ID P07) For each selected year this report gives a detailed description by sector of the target outputs, manpower requirements, and achievable outputs based on existing manpower. It contains: A. Target Sector Product Output; B. Achievable Output; C. Shortfall; D. Total Manpower Required; E. Available National Manpower; F. Available Expatriate Manpower; G. Additional Expatriate Manpower Required; H. Expatriate Manpower Replacing Expatriate Attrition; and I. Net Growth of Expatriates. (P08) Available National Manpower Pool Analyses (Report ID POB) For each selected year this report gives a detailed analysis of the available national manpower by pool. It contains:
 - 18 - A. Pool stock at start of year; B. ESM additions; C. Other additions or deletions; D. Labor excess over sector/occupation matrix cell targets; E. Distribution to sector/occupation matrix cells; and F. Pool stock at end of year, categorized by waiting times. (PO9) Regional Manpower Leakage Anallsis (Report ID P09) For each selected year this report gives a detailed analysis of the labor force leakages from a selected locality by pool. For each pool the number of total leakers available for reallocation is given as well as the number of leakers distri- buted to each locality. (PlO) Global Analyses of Target Outputs and Achievable Outputs (Report ID PlO) For selected report years this global report combines the information contained in the P07 reports for individual localities. In addition to the individual locality figures, a comparison of total outputs is presented. Highlights Reports include: (HOl) Labor Force Highlights Report by Year (Report ID B01) This report summarizes the labor force on a yearly basis, including: A. the labor force broken down by nationality; B. the total number of expatriates imported or exported;
 - 19 - C. the total net growth of expatriate labor force; D. the percent of nationals in the total labor force; E. the percent of nationals in each sector of the labor force; F. the percent of nationals in each occupation of the labor force; G. the percent of the total GDP attributable to nationals in the labor force; E. the percent of the sector-group GDP attributable to nationals in the labor force for each defined sector- group; and I. the number of surplus nationals (if any) listed by pool.
 - 20 - Section 4.0 System Inputs The input to the system consists of a card deck and optionally a master file. This section will describe: (1) How a master file is used as part of the input; (2) What data are required. Since the master file is in the same format as the data cards this section will first describe the general card format to be used. Secondly, the master file will be described including the rules for updating. The remainder of the section will describe the cards needed for the various sections of the model.
 - 21 - 4.1 General Card Format Although the data items vary for each card type, the first ten columns are similar. This field is reserved to contain system identification information as described below: Card Column Description 1 Card type identifier which identifies the submodel or type of data being entered. 2 - 3 Remainder of the card type identifier. These are numeric digits (e.g., "02"). 4 - 6 Locality identification field. These 3 characters are available to the user to identify the locality associated with the data. The following codes can be entered: ID - three-character locality identifier (defined on a GOB card). "GLB" - global data "ALL" - data applies to all localities (and global if appropriate) which do not otherwise appear in the input with the same card type in columns 1-3. (Thus "ALL" may be used to enter data for some or all localities.) 7 -10 Sequence number field which is used to generate the desired order of input of cards of the same type. It is also used in the updating procedure described in Section 4.2.
 - 22 - 4.2 Master File The master file is used to allow the user to submit smaller input decks. This section will describe the use of the file on input. In either Update ("U") or Sensitivity ("S") runs the edit program will first merge the entire input data deck with the input data stored in the master file specified on the input card. This merge procedure will make use of the card ID (Col 1-3), locality identifier (Col 4-6), and the card sequence number (Col 7-10). The main features of the updating are shown in the table below: Feature Description of Row to Use REPLACE Duplicate card ID, locality identifier, and card sequence number of card to be replaced. INSERT Use card sequence number not in master file. This number may be duplicated in the input deck if more than one card is to be inserted. DELETE Duplicate card ID, locality identifier and card sequence number of card to be deleted. Place DELETE in Col 11-16. DELETE A GROUP (ALL Duplicate card ID, locality identifier and card SAME ID AND LOCALITY) sequence number of first card to be deleted. Place DELETE in Col 11-16, add last sequence in Column 17-20. The last sequence need not appear on any card of the master file. In the event that a new master file is written, the output will be resequenced starting at 0001 and incrementing by 2 for each card type and locality. A listing will be generated at the same time.
 - 23 - Figure 4.1 illustrates part of an update run. Only the card ID, locality ID (R04) and sequence numbers are listed. The left-most column con- tains a section of the original master file, the next column contains the input update cards, next is the resultant update and then is shown a resequenced version of the updated information: the new master file. The right-most column contains a description of the updating operations.

 - 25 - 4.3 Card INPUT The inputs to the system can be classified into the following major categories: - System Control Input - Labor Force Data - Manpower Requirements - Education/Training and Manpower Supply Data - Manpower Policies Data This section will provide an overview of the card input and describe the data to be entered on each card. Appendix A gives a complete description of each card. 4.3.1 System Control Input This system control input cards allow the user to: - Enter a description of the simulation run being requested; - Select the number of years of simulation desired and the interval of reports to be generated by the system; - Enter analyst names, title and ministries/organizations; - Select the types of reports desired, footnotes and their distribution; and - Define the codes and give labels for sectors, occupations, nationalities, localities, and labor pools. The system control is contained on the C and G cards.
 - 26 - Number of Card ID Descriptive Title Cards Necessary COI Run Parameters Card 1 per run C02 Title Card(s) 1 set per locality + global C03 Report Year Selection Card 1 per locality + global G01 Analysts ID Card 1 set per locality + global G02 Sector Definition Card 1 set (global) G03 Occupation Definition Card 1 set (global) G04 Nationality Definition Card 1 set (global) G05 Report Selection Card 1 set per locality + global G06 Report Distribution List Card 1 set per locality + global G07 Footnote Card 1 set per locality + global GOS Locality Definition Card 1 set (global) G09 Pool Definition Card 1 set (global) GIO Sector Group Definition 1 set (global) The C01 card allows users to define a base year and to select any number of simulation years desired. It also contains a flag indicating if a new master file is desired. Tne C02 card set allows users to enter any description about the simulation run being requested. The description contained in the first card
 - 27 - will be printed at the top of each page of the reports generated by the system. Any additional carl, are printed at the beginning of the reports. Although not required it is strongly recommended that a complete description of the run be made by the user. Each locality can have its own C02 card set. The C03 card is entered for each locality and used to define the years of reports. The GOI cards allow users to identify themselves on the simulation output. There could be as many of these cards as the ntumber of people in- volved in the analyses. If these cards are present, the information provided will be printed on the output reports. The G02 set of cards allows users to define sector ID's and descrip- tions. The sector ID's provided in this set of cards must be used consistently throughout the simulation run and will constitute a dictionary. The ID's entered could be alpha-numeric combinations. This set of cards is required. The G03 set of cards allows users to define occupation ID's and descriptions in a manner consistent with the sector definition cards. The occupation ID's must be consistent throughout the simulation run. This set of cards is required. The G04 set of cards allows users to define nationality ID's and descriptions in a manner consistent with the sector definition card. The nationality ID's must be consistent throughout a given simulation run. One set of cards is required for each simulation run. The G05 cards allows users to select reports provided by the sys- tem. The user may select different reports from each of the localities as well as global reports. The user can:
 - 28 - (1) Identify the reports desired; (2) Identify the reports not wanted (remainder generated); (3) Specify that "ALL" are wanted; or (4) Specify that none are wanted. If this card is not entered reports can later be selected with a report phase control card. The G06 set of cards allows users to specify the distribution list of reports selected, number of copies to be distributed for each recipient, etc. The information provided on this card will be printed on reports produced by the system. This card is optional. The G07 set of cards allows users to attach footnotes to selected reports. A footnote may be continued on a second card by duplicating the report ID and the footnote number. The footnotes will be printed in the order that they are found in the input deck. The footnote will only apply to reports from the locality. If the footnote is desired to appear on a specific report from more than one locality, it must be entered for all of the desired localities or using "ALL" as the locality designator if it is to be printed for all localities. The G08 set of cards allows users to define locality ID's and descriptions in a manner consistent with the sector definition card. One set of G08 cards is required for each simulation run. The G09 set of cards allows users to define pool ID's and descrip- tions in a manner consistent with the sector definition cards. One set of G09 cards is required for each simulation run. The GIO set of cards allows users to define a sector grouping to be used in the HOI report. This set of cards is optional; if the cards are not
 - 29 - used then the sector grouping portion of the HOI report will not be printed if the HOl report is selected. 4.3.2 Labor Force Input This input is used to define the labor force in the locality. It allows users to enter: (1) The base year labor force; (2) Attrition rates; (3) Leakage rates for nationals. The labor force input is briefly described below: Card Number of ID Description Cards Necessary LOI Base Year Nationals labor force 1 set per locality L02 Attrition rates - Nationals 1 set per locality L03 Base year expatriate labor force 1 set per locality L04 Attrition rates - Expatriates 1 set per locality L05 Leakage rates - Nationals 1 set per locality The LO1 set of cards allows users to provide data on the existing national labor force by sector and occupation in the base year. The sector/occupation ID's entered on this card or set of cards must have been defined in card G02 and card G03. Any cells not filled are assumed to con- tain no national workers in the base year. This card set is required for each locality in the simulation run. The L02 set of cards allows users to specify attrition rates for national labor force by year, by occupation/sector. In order to ease the input preparation the keyword "ALL" may be used in either Sector or Occupation ID field to identify a constant value across the sector or occupation ID field
 - 30 - to identify a constant value across the sector or occupation. Attrition rates remain in effect until changed by a subsequent card. They are all initialized to zero in the base year. The L03 set of cards has a similar meaning as Card LOI, Base Year National Labor Force Card, except that the nationality ID's must be entered in this card. If this card is not used the base year expatriate labor counts are zero. The L04 set of cards has a similar meaning as Card L02, National Labor Force Attrition Card, except that the nationality ID's must be entered in this card. In the international case, attritional expatriates will be returned to their home country without any time lag. "ALL" may be used as a Sector, Occupation, or Nationality ID. The L05 set of cards is used to identify nationals within the locality that will leave the locality during the year. They are reassigned to other localities using the Leakage Distribution Cards (P05) as well as the time lag card (P04). This set of cards is similar to the L02 cards in that entries are made for each Sector/Occupation. "ALL" has a similar meaning. 4.3.3 Manpower Requirements Input The manpower requirement input allows users to calculate the pro- jected required labor force at the sector-occupation level. This is done by calculating the requirements at the sectoral level and then using distribution rates to estimate the occupational distribution. The user can enter data for any two of: sector product output; sector productivity; sector employment. The third one is computed from the two entered as data. The same two need not be entered for every sector. (If all three are entered for a sector then the sector productivity entered as
 - 31 - data is not used, but is checked to ensure that it is within 5% of the value computed by dividing sector output by sector employment.) Each of the three sector quantities can be specified directly on a yearly basis, or growth rates can be specified to be,applied after a particu- lar year. In addition, if values are entered for two non-successive years then the data for intermediate years will be computed by interpolation. The occupation distribution rates may be entered on a yearly basis. They may also be interpolated between values for non-successive years. The manpower requirements cards are summarized in the table below: Card ID Description D 2 Base year sector product output D03 Sector product streaming (yearly) D05 Sector product output growth D08 Base year sector productivity D09 Sector productivity streaming (yearly) Dll Sector productivity growth rate D14 Base year sectoral employment D15 Sectoral employment growth rate D19 Sectoral employment streaming (yearly) D20 Sectoral/occupation employment distribu- tion rates The D02 set of cards allows users to enter base year sectoral out- put. The choice of units for use in sector output and sector productivity is arbitrary but it is left to the user to make certain that consistent units are used. Sector output divided by productivity should yield total manpower.
 - 32 - Tne D03 card can be used to enter sector product output for years after the base year. Values will be interpolated for years not specified between years which are specified. Values after the last year entered with D03 cards are computed using growth rates from the D05 card. The growth rates are entered as pecentages on the D05 card and remain in effect until replaced. The Sectoral Productivity is entered in a manner consistent with the Sectoral Product Output. The D08 set of cards allows users to enter base year sectoral productivities. The D09 and Dll cards are used in a fashion analagous to the D03 and D05 cards. The base year sectoral employment must be entered using the D14 card if it differs from that obtained by summing the values on the LOI and L03 cards. The D19 and D15 cards are used in a fashion analogous to the D03 and D05 cards. The sectoral employment estimates are calculated for each sector as a whole. The D20 card set is used to obtain sector/occupational distribution of a given sectoral employment. Summation across occupational classification for a,given sector must be equal to 100X. This distribution defaults to the distribution of employees in the base year (LOI and L03 cards). Data are specified by year. If data are not specified for a year they are interpolated between the closest years before and after that year; values after the last year specified default to the last year. 4.3.4 Educational Training System Input The Educational/Training Simulation Model (ESM) or ETS, is used to train Nationals and pool the graduates and dropouts by labor skill for entry into the work force. The input for this section is contained on "E" and "S" cards which allow the user to:
 - 33 - Define the educational structure Set base year enrollments Identify intakes to the system Specify promotion, dropout and repetition rates Define teacher groups Define manpower pools in terms of educational qualification and probability that the individual will enter labor force Maintain school age population by age and sex * Maintain "leakage" of nationals from the region upon graduation The cards used are described in the table below: Card ID Description EO0 ESM initialization E03 Base year course enrollment E04 Course structure description E05 Teacher group titles E06 Promotion/repetition/dropout rates E07 Entrance levels E09 Student/teacher ratio El0 Associated population movements S04 Base year underaged school leavers S05 Labor force participation matrix S06 School leavers pooling S09 Underage participation rates Sio Additional national labor SIl ESM leakage rates
 - 34 - The same educational structure is used for all localities. The E01 card is used to define the constants and sizes of the system. It contains: The number of courses (maximum of 300) The number of age groups per course (maximum of 6) The number of teacher groups (maximum of 30) The minimum legal age to work The minimum age to enter school The Dummy courses to be used for males and females who have never attended school The E03 cards are used to enter the base year enrollments of the courses described using E04 cards. An E03 card must be present for each course and each locality. It contains an entry for each age group within each course. The structure of the system is described using E04 cards. These cards describe each course in terms of: Course title (24 characters) Associated teacher group Ideal age of enrollment Follow-on courses that graduates of this course are qualified to enter * Sex of enrollees in this course One set of E04 cards is required for the simulation. The E05 card is used to enter teacher group titles. The same titles apply for all localities. The E06 set of cards is used to identify the fraction of the course enrollees who will repeat or dropout of the course. The remainder graduates
 - 35 - are distributed to the various follow-on courses using the Promotion Distri- bution Data (PRDD's) provided. These may be entered each year and remain in effect until replaced. The E07 cards are used to provide the entrance levels into various courses. Any course may be identified on an E07 card. The E09 card is used to enter the student/teacher ratio. This in- formation is used to estimate the size of the teacher labor force. The program will use the E10 card to estimate population changes as a function of labor force migration. The population change from year to year will be used to adjust the sizes of the ESM courses. As has been previously described, ESM also groups like educational skills together in labor pools. This is done by requiring the user to enter a complete list of which courses enter which pool. This is accomplished by means of the S06 set of cards. As the courses are upgraded in future years the corresponding pool can be changed. The S05 set of cards is used to specify participation rates to be applied to the graduates and dropouts from each course before placing them in the pools. The underaged school leavers are held by course number and age until they reach the minimum age to work. The S04 set of cards is used to initialize the pools in the base year. The S09 set of cards is used to allow some of the underaged to "illegally" enter the labor force prior to reaching the minimum age to work. The S10 card set allows additional entries or withdrawals from the labor pools. It can be used by the user to retrain members of various pools.
 - 36 - The Sll card is used to identify the school leavers who will leave the locality in search of employment. The rates will be by pool and thus be effective for all ESM leavers. 4.3.5 Manpower Policy Input The Manpower Policy Model inputs are contained on "P" cards. These inputs allow users to: Enter the correspondence between labor pools and sector/ occupation cells Enter the nationalization levels Enter priorities for worker distribution Maintain regional population by nationality and age group Enter desired ratio of expatriates groups to fulfill any manpower shortages. The cards used in this submodel are described below: Card ID Description PO1 Associated Labor Pool Identification P02 Nationalization Goals P03 Priority of Sector/Occupation P04 Time Lag of Nationals Allocation P05 Leakage Allocation P06 Population Group Definition P07 Base Year Population P09 Associated Population Movement P10 Expatriate Distribution P1l Base Year Labor Force in Transition P12 Birth Rate P13 Population Mortality Rates
 - 37 - A separate policy model may be set up for each locality. With the exception of the P06 card, the remainder are used for each locality. The P01 card is used to identify the manpower pool corresponding with each sector/occupation cell. The special identifier "ALL" may be used in a manner similar to the L01 card to allow ease of data entry. The P02 card contains Nationalization goals in percent. The employment level for Nationals will never exceed this level and it will be used in the manpower allocation routine as part of the distribution scheme. The default for cells not entered is 100.0 percent. The P03 card contains the cell priorities. Cells with the highest priority will draw their allotment from the pool first. The reallocation of ESM and labor force leakages is accomplished by introducing a time lag distribution and a regional distribution card. Nationals from each locality who depart the locality will be grouped into the standard labor pools. Time lag distribution, which can be entered by the user for each pool and varied every year, is entered on a P04 card. Three numbers are entered giving the percent of pool members to be reallocated in one, two and three years. (Those not reallocated in one, two or three years are allo- cated immediately.) The P05 card contains the distribution fractions and con- trols how many Nationals will migrate to various regions. It may be changed on an annual basis. The Pll card set is used by the user to indicate the number of Nationals in transition by labor pool during the base year. The card is optional and defaults to zero. In order to assist in the analysis of required regional infrastruc- tures, the Manpower Policy Model will maintain a regional population by Nation- ality and age group. The P06 card set, which is entered with the global
 - 38 - data, will define the age groupings. Male and Female population figures will be separately maintained withit each age -group. The P07 card set is used to enter the population in the base year. Birth rates and mortality rates are entered on the P12 and P13 cards, respectively. The P09 card will allow the user to indicate a deviation in aver- age family size and structure from the Regional Norm. Associated non-labor force population movement will be calculated for both workers entering and leaving the region. The progran will default to the population distribution of the Nationality involved. The P09 card will allow users to indicate a different population distribution, if desired. The final user input allows the user to alter the ratio of expa- triate groups working in a specific sector/occupation. After allocation of Nationals and expatriates leaked from other regions of the solution, the model allocates expatriates to fill any remaining jobs. This allocation is made at the same ratio as the various Nationalities are currently working in the country. The P10 card allows the user the option of altering that ratio.

 - 42 - 4.5 CARD PUNCHING CONVENTIONS A complete description of each type of card is given in Appendix A. This section includes some general notes on conventions to be observed when punching cards (or preparing data sheets for punching). 4.5.1 Numeric Values Values which are indicated in the card descriptions of Appendix A as integer must be punched without a decimal point. They should also be punched as far to the right as possible within the field. Values which are not integer can be punched with or without a decimal point and may have a fractional part if a decimal point is used. If the dec=inal point is not used, the value should be punched as far to the right as possible within the field. A non-integer numeric value may also be expressed in scientific (exponential) form. In this case a number is followed by the letter E and an integer. The value represented is the number multiplied by 10 raised to the power denoted by the integer following E. For example 6.8E5 represents 680000; 3.22E-4 represents .000322. 4.5.2 Identifiers Identifiers (or ID's) such as sector identifiers and occupation identifiers are entered in 3-column fields. Any alphanumeric combination of characters can be used for an identifier. It is recommended that strings of characters be used which abbreviate the name of the group being identified; e.g., "AGR" for agriculture, "PRO" for professional, "ARB" for Arabian, etc. If an ID has fewer than three characters then the characters must be posi- tioned within the 3-column field in exactly the same way each time the ID is used. Also, blanks alLd zeros are not equivalent in an ID (as they are at
 - 43 - the beginning of a itumeric field). For example, all of these are different ID's: it"1","1 1 it, is 1", "001"l. 4.5.3 Consistencv of Units The user must ensure that consistent units are used throughout the input data. This is especially important in the case of sector outputs and productivity, where there is a great deal of freedom in choosing the units.

 - 57 - E04 Card Format Educational Structure Description Card Card Columns Description 1-3 "E04" 4-6 Not used 7-10 Card sequence number 11-13 Course number 14 Sequence number of the card within the course 15-38 Course name 39-40 Teacher group number 41-42 Ideal age 43 Code identifying sex of students 44-46 1st follow-on course 47-49 2nd follow-on course 50-52 3rd follow-on course 53-55 4th follow-on course 56-58 5th follow-on course 59-61 6th follow-on course 62-64 7th follow-on course 65-67 8th follow-on course 68-70 9th follow-on course 71-73 10th follow-on course 74-76 11th follow-on course 77-79 12th follow-on course Note: (1) Course number must be a positive integer less than or equal to the number of courses defined on the E01 card. (2) Course name is any 24 character name. (3) Teacher group is a positive integer less than or equal to the number of teacher groups as defined on the E01 card. (4) Ideal age is a positive integer greater than the minimum age to enter school as defined on the E01 card. (5) Follow-on courses must be positive integers less than or equal to the number of courses defined on the E0I card. Unused follow-on course fields should be left blank. (6) Student sex codes are: blank for both sexes; "M" for males; "F" for females. (7) The follow-on course 999 indicates that the graduates are to enter the labor force.
 - 58 - (8) Only one card is needed for a course if there are 12 or fewer follow-on courses. In this case the sequence number in column 14 is not used. If these are more than 12 follow-on courses column 14 is used to sequence the successive cards for the course; columns 15-43 are not used on cards after the first one for the course. (9) A course need not have any follow-on courses. (In this case all graduates of the course become available to participate in the labor force.)
 - 59 - E05 Card Format Teacher Group Titles Card Columus Description 1-3 "E05" 4-6 Not used 7-10 Card sequence number 11-12 Teacher group number 13-36 Teacher group title Note: (1) The teacher group number must be a positive integer and may not exceed the number of teacher groups specified on the E01 card. (2) If a title is not entered for a teacher group the title "TEACEER GROUP n" is used where n is the teacher group number.
 - 60 - E06 Card Format PRDD and Repetition/Dropout Data Cards Card Columns Description 1-3 "E06" 4-6 Locality ID 7-10 Card sequence number 11-14 Year of the data contained on these cards 15-17 Beginning course number 18 Sequence number of the card within the course 19-21 Ending course number 22 Flag to denote data specification. If 0 or blank-R/D and PRDD present If 1-R/D only present If 2-PRDD only present If 3- the R/D and PRDD values are added to last years value to obtain new R/D and PRDD 23-26 Repetition rate 27-30 Dropout rate 31-34 PRDD for the first follow-on course 35-38 PRDD for the second follow-on course 39-42 PRDD for the third follow-on course 43-46 PRDD for the fourth follow-on course 47-50 PRDD for the fifth follow-on course 51-54 PRDD for the sixth follow-on course 55-58 PRDD for the seventh follow-on course 59-62 PRDD for the eighth follow-on course 63-66 PRDD for the ninth follow-on course 67-70 PRDD for the tenth follow-on course 71-74 PRDD for the eleventh follow-on course 75-78 PRDD for the twelfth follow-on course Note: (1) Year must be greater than the base year on the COI card. (2) Course numbers must be positive integers less than or equal to the number of courses on the E01 card. Ending course number must be greater than or equal to the beginning course number, and may be blank if the data on the card applies to only one course. (3) Data are expressed as rates in the range 0 to 1. (4) The sum of the repetition and dropout rates cannot exceed 1. (5) Locality ID must be "ALL" or the ID of a locality defined on a G08 card.
 - 61 - E06 Card Format (Contd.) (6) Data applies until replaced, and must be entered completely for the first year. (7) Only one card is needed for a course if there are 12 or fewer follow-on courses. In this case the sequence number in column 18 is not used. If there are more than 12 follow-on courses column 18 is used to sequence the successive cards for the course; columns 19-30 are not used on cards after the first one for the course. (8) The number of PRDD's for a course must be equal to the number of follow- on courses for the course, as specified on the E04 card. Unused PRDD fields should be left blank. (9) The sum of the PURD's for a course cannot exceed 1.0. If the sum, s, is less than 1.0 then the unspecified fraction 1-s of the graduates becomes available to participate in the labor force.

(2) Course number must be a positive integer less than or equal to the number of courses on the E01 card. (3) Entrance levels are non-negative integers. (4) Data applies until replaced. (5) Locality ID must be "ALL" or the ID of a locality defined on a G08 card. (6) Entrance levels for courses not specified are taken to be zero. (7) Only as many fields on the card should be used to enter entrance levels as there are age groups per course (defined on the EO1 card).

 - 64 - E10 Card Format Associated Population Movement Data Card Card Columns Description 1-3 "E10" 4-6 Locality ID 7-10 Card sequence number 11-14 Year of the data contained on this card 15-17 Not used 18-20 Pool ID 21-22 Age 23-28 Associated movement of males (per 1000) 29-34 Associated movement of females (per 1000) 35-36 Age 37-42 Associated movement of males (per 1000) 43-48 Associated movement of females (per 1000) 49-50 Age 51-56 Associated movement of males (per 1000) 57-62 Associated movement of females (per 1000) 63-64 Age 65-70 Associated movement of males (per 1000) 71-76 Associated movement of females (per 1000) Note: (1) Year must be greater than the base year on the C01 card.  - 84 - P04 Card Format Time Lag of Nationals Allocation Card Columns Description 1-3 "P04" 4-6 Locality ID 7-10 Card sequence number 11-14 Year of data contained on this card 15-17 Pool ID 18-20 Percent who must wait one year 21-23 Percent who must wait two years 24-26 Percent who must wait three years 27-29 Pool ID 30-32 Percent who must wait one year 33-35 Percent who must wait two years 36 38 Percent who must wait three years 39-41 Pool ID 42-44 Percent who must wait one year 45-47 Percent who must wait two years 48-50 Percent who must wait three years 51-53 Pool ID 54-56 Percent who must wait one year 57-59 Percent who must wait two years 60-62 Percent who must wait three years 63-65 Pool ID 66-68 Percent who must wait one year 69-71 Percent who must wait two years 72-74 Percent who must wait three years Note: (1) Year must be greater than the base year on the COI card. (2) Pool ID must be defined on a G09 card, or "ALL" to specify all pools. (3) The sum of the percents for a pool cannot exceed 100. The percent who do not have to wait at all -(i.e. allocated immediately) is defined as 100 minus the sum of the percents waiting one, two and three years. (4) If percents are not defined for a pool, then all members of the pool are allocated immediately, as though the percents for one, two and three years were all zero. (5) Data applies until replaced. (6) Locality ID must be "ALL" or the ID of a locality defined on a G08 card.

(9) Locality ID must be "ALL" or the ID of a locality defined on a G08 card.

Messages begin in one of two ways: *** ERROR - message text ****** WARNING - message text ERROR messages are listed in alphabetical order in the first part of the appendix. WARNING messages are listed in alphabetical order in the last part of the appendix, beginning on page C-25.

The message is followed by a line giving an error code which will aid a programmer in locating the source of the error. The run is i=mediately terminated with the message RUN ABANDONED. You should retry the run beginning with the edit phase so that a new edited input file is produced. If the problem persists all output from the run including the edit phase output should be forwarded to TASS for analysis. doc.repnme: Tools for manpower planning - the World Bank models / user's guide for the regional (expanded) model - volume III
doc.abstracts: The Regional (Expanded) Model is one of a set of simulation models developed during a research project to study the implications of the explosion of international migration in the Middle East and North Africa Region for both labor-importing and labor-exporting countries. The models have been applied to study manpower problems and planning issues in several countries and proven to be a useful tool. This user's guide describes the input, output, use and operation of the model, which is a manpower forecasting model, implemented for IBM 370 systems.
